item.title: Assignment
item.description: Table of contents Table of contents Learning goals GWAS project Looking at the data Odds ratios for one contingency table Many odds ratios Look for a biological signal in the genome using the odds ratios Chi^2 calculations Correction for continuity Simulating/permuting the null distribution Trying Fisher’s exact test Making a Manhattan plot and correcting for multiple testing The distribution of the significant SNPs in the genome Learning goals By the end of this session, you should be able to… calculate odds ratios by hand and associated values (confidence intervals etc.

item.title: Week 8: The Poisson distribution
item.description: library(ggplot2) Table of contents Table of contents Learning goals Exercises R functions for simulating from /calculating the Poisson probability distribution Mastering POISSON distributions calculations: example of genome sequencing Example 8.6 of the book “Extinctions” in R Questions from Chapter 8 Problems Planning a metagenome sequencing experiment Learning goals By the end of this session, you should be able to… master Goodness-of-fit tests: What null is tested, what degrees of freedom are appropriate?

item.title: Week 7: Goodness of fit
item.description: Table of contents Table of contents Learning goals Exercises R functions for simulating from /calculating the Chi^2 probability distribution Mastering Chi^2 distributions using dchisq() pchisq() and rchisq() No weekend getaway Gene content of the human X chromosome Designer 2 child families Chapter 8 exercises Learning goals By the end of this session, you should be able to… Understand Goodness-of-fit tests: How do we quantify lack of fit for frequency data: the chi2 test stastistic?

item.title: Week 6: Analyzing proportions
item.description: library(tidyverse) # I will need this later for fancy plotting Table of contents Table of contents Learning goals Exercises Introducing dbinom() and rbinom() Visualizing the binomial distribution in R Example 7.2 of the book “Sex and the X” in R Chapter 7 Problems Planning a survey according to statistical power Learning goals By the end of this session, you should be able to… understand several key concepts within hypothesis testing: null hypothesis & null distribution test statistic & P-values which errors can we make when performing hypothesis testing (I and II) what is statistical power understand the binomial distribution and in what context it arises how the binomial probability distribution can be used as a null distribution when testing null hypothesis with proportion data README FIRST :-) We first introduce/illustrate two important new R functions: dbinom() and rbinom().

item.title: Week 5: Hypothesis testing
item.description: Table of contents Table of contents Learning goals Exercises Sampling Simulating a null distribution using 1 million simulations Basic probability calculations P values by comparing the test statistic to the null distribution Learning goals By the end of this session, you should be able to… Understand conditional probability Understand Bayes theorem: how to calculate the conditional probability Understand several key concepts within hypothesis testing Null hypothesis Null distribution Test statistic P value (probability of observing the value of the test statistic if the null hypothesis were true) Exercises Sampling This is how you can simulate data:

item.title: Week 4: Probability
item.description: Table of contents Table of contents Learning goals Exercises Problem A Problem B Learning goals By the end of this session, you should be able to… Calculate probabilities by hand Calculate expectation and variance of a random variable Calculate the expectation and variance of a sum of n random variables and relate this to the terms: SD of a population SE of a sample Exercises Problem A A1.

item.title: Week 3: Sampling distributions
item.description: Table of contents Table of contents Loading libraries Problem 9 Exercises Reproducing in R the Figure 4.1-1 & important details of histogram drawing in R Generating Figure 4.1-2 Reproducing Figures 4.1-3 and 4.1-4 Trying and evalutating the +/- 2 SEs rule of thumb Loading libraries library(abd) #we need to load the ABD dataset to be able to access the YeastGenes data in Exercise 1 library(cowplot) #this is just for plotting but you don't need to worry about it Chapter 4, Problem 9 One of the great discoveries of biology is that organisms have a class of genes called “regulatory genes”, whose only job is to regulate the activity of other genes.

item.title: Week 2: Summary statistics
item.description: Table of contents Table of contents Learning goals Exercises Calculating summary statistics in a sample Summarizing and visualizing the Stickleback data of Chapter 3 Developing your intuition for histograms and boxplots Making up your own data by sampling from a theoretical distribution Learning goals By the end of this session, you should be able to… load datasets in R from the ABD package calculate summary statistics by hand and using the summary stats functions in R slice data in R (selecting subsets of data) create data but also sample data from a first theoretical distribution and discuss how much samples from this distribution are close to the real observed data be good at making the correspondance between summary statistics (mean, median, SD, etc.
